fields: For a {{c1::speed}} event, glycolysis is performed anaerobically in Type {{c1::II}} cells. As glycolysis is turned to lactate, pH drops from 7 to 6 causing muscle {{c1::fatigue}}.

Oxidation of glucose/lactate 
{{c1::Glucose}} from liver glycogen can enter muscle (>1 minute)
In the presence of sufficient O2, {{c2::pyruvate}} enters the  TCA cycle in the mitochondria followed by oxidative phosphorylation in the Electron Transport Chain resulting in adequate ATP production.
{{c3::Lactate}} from fast twitch muscles can enter slow twitch muscles where it is oxidized.
{{c3::Lactate}} can also travel to the liver for gluconeogenesis

The mobilization of {{c1::lipids}} from adipocytes usually occurs during exercise lasting longer than 30-40 minutes
The {{c2::fatty acids}} can then enter the skeletal muscle
Intramuscular fatty acids are normally {{c3::oxidized}} during recovery following prolonged exertion

Gluconeiogenesis:
{{c1::Hepatic}} gluconeogenesis becomes increasingly important as exercise is prolonged beyond an hour and {{c2::hepatic glycogen}} stores become depleted.
The most important substrates for hepatic gluconeogenesis are {{c3::lactate and alanine.}}
During prolonged exercise, the key substrate is {{c4::lactate}} released into the circulation by contracting skeletal muscle for uptake by the liver, which resynthesizes glucose for uptake by the muscle via the {{c5::Cori cycle}}

Muscle Fatigue Overview:
1. Fatigued muscle produces less force and has a reduced velocity of {{c2::shortening (contraction}} rate)
2. Central fatigue is due to changes in the {{c1::CNS}}
 3. Peripheral fatigue is due to changes within the {{c3::muscle}}:

Fatigued muscle 
Muscle {{c2::fatigue}} is defined as the inability to maintain a desired power output:
  Results from a decline in both {{c1::force}} and velocity of {{c1::shortening}}.

A decline in maximal force production results from:
  Reduction in the {{c2::number}} of active {{c1::actin-myosin}} cross-bridges
  Reduction of the {{c3::force}} produced per {{c1::actin-myosi}}n cross-bridge
Impaired release and reuptake of {{c1::Ca2+}} from the {{c2::sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR)}} can result in difficult or impossible fast movements

Central fatigue is due to:
1)altered input from {{c1::muscle sensory nerve fibers}} to the brain
1)altered excitability of {{c2::motor neurons}} to the muscle.
1)reduced excitatory input to motor control centers of the {{c3::brain}} and {{c3::spinal cord}}

The identification of specific sites involved in central fatigue is
difficult because of the complexity of the {{c1::CNS}}. 
Nevertheless, {{c2::external sensory input}}, such as shouting and
cheering, can often increase muscle force production and
physical performance

Peripheral fatigue:
A. {{c1::ATP}} depletion. Muscle fibers require {{c2::ATP}} for contraction, relaxation, and the activity of the membrane pumps that maintain ionic homeostasis. Therefore, the cells must maintain [{{c2::ATP}}]i to avoid fatigue

. Lactic acid accumulation. The fall in pH:
  Inhibits {{c1::myosin ATPase}} activity and thereby reduces the velocity of shortening.
  Inhibits {{c2::cross-bridge}} interaction between actin and myosin and the binding of {{c3::Ca 2+}} to {{c4::troponin}}
  Inhibits the {{c5::Na-K}} pump
  Inhibits {{c6::phosphofructokinase}}, the rate-limiting step of muscle glycolysis.

{{c1::Glycogen}} depletion. 
During exercise the eventual decrease in {{c2::glycogen}} stores in muscle fibers decreases power output.

The body improves its capacity to perform work through physical exertion.
However, one must meet {{c5::four}} conditions to achieve a training effect, or adaptation to exercise.
1.The intensity of the activity must be relatively {{c4::high}}. For aerobic training (e.g., running, cycling, and swimming), the level of stress increases with the speed of the activity.
●
2.Each period of activity must be of sufficient {{c1::duration}}.
●
3.One must {{c2::repeat}} the activity over time on a regular basis (e.g., several times per week).
●
4.Finally, sufficient rest must occur between each training session because adaptations occur during the {{c3::recovery}} period.

1.Increasing cardiac output as a result of:
  a.    {{c1::Hypertrophy}} of the heart
  b. Increased {{c2::cardiac stroke volume}} as a result of expansion of the {{c3::plasma}} compartment

Trained muscle can accommodate a greater maximal {{c1::blood}} flow because of the
growth of new {{c2::microvessels}}, particularly capillaries.
  - Well-conditioned individuals have a 60% {{c3::greater::more or less}} number of {{c4::capillaries}} per cross-sectional area of muscle than do sedentary people.

Increased capillary density increases {{c1::O2}} delivery and thus provides:
1.Greater {{c2::surface area}} for diffusion
2.Reduction of the diffusion distance for {{c3::O2}} between the capillary and muscle fibers

Aerobic training enhances O2 diffusion into muscle
in addition
1. Increased {{c1::capillary}} length and volume
 2. Prolonged transit time of {{c2::red blood}} cells along capillaries, and thereby promotes the extraction of O2 and nutrients from the blood as well as the removal of metabolic byproducts.

Endurance training can increase the mitochondrial content of skeletal muscle fibers nearly {{c1::2}}-fold
  -  By stimulating the synthesis of mitochondrial enzymes and other proteins 
-  Promotes {{c2::O2}} extraction from the blood. 
  - Primary benefit from mitochondrial adaptation in aerobic conditioning is the capacity to {{c4::oxidize}} substrates, particularly fat, an ability that enhances {{c3::endurance}} of muscle.
Sweat glands are of two types: {{c1::apocrine}} and {{c1::eccrine}}.
The apocrine sweat glands, located in the {{c1::axillary}} and {{c1::anogenital}} regions of the body, are relatively few in number (∼100,000) and large in diameter (2 to 3 mm).

These glands, which often become active during {{c1::puberty}}, produce a turbid and viscous secretion that is rich in {{c2::lipids}} and {{c2::carbohydrates}} and carries a characteristic body odor.
Apocrine sweat glands have no role in temperature regulation in humans, although they may act as a source of {{c3::pheromones}}

{{c1::Eccrine}} sweat glands are distributed over the majority of the body surface, are numerous (several million), and are small in diameter (50 to 100 μm). 
The {{c2::palms of the hands}} and {{c2::soles of the feet}} tend to have both larger and more densely distributed {{c1::eccrine}} glands than elsewhere
Sweat production is quantitatively less in {{c1::women}} than in {{c1::men}}, a finding reflecting less output per gland rather than fewer eccrine sweat glands.

An eccrine sweat gland is a simple tubular epithelium composed of a {{c1::coiled gland}} and a {{c2::duct}}.
A rich {{c3::microvascular}} network surrounds the entire sweat gland.
The coiled gland, located deep in the dermis, is innervated by {{c4::sympathetic}} fibers that are {{c5::cholinergic}}.
The release of {{c1::acetylcholine}} stimulates the {{c3::acinar}} cells and causes them to secrete into the lumen a clear, odorless solution, similar in composition to {{c2::protein-free plasma}}.
Along the way, duct cells reabsorb {{c1::salt}} and some water until the fluid reaches the skin surface through an opening, the sweat pore

With {{c1::mild}} stimulation of acinar cells, the small volume of primary secretion travels {{c2::slowly}} along the duct, and the ducts reabsorb nearly all the {{c3::Na+}} and {{c3::Cl-}}, which can fall to final concentrations as low as ∼5 mM.

With strong {{c1::cholinergic}} stimulation, a large volume of primary secretion travels {{c3::rapidly}} along the duct, so the load exceeds the capacity of the ductal epithelium to reabsorb {{c2::Na+}} and {{c2::Cl-}}.

As the body acclimates to high rates of {{c1::eccrine}} sweat production, the ability to reabsorb {{c2::NaCl}} increases, and the result is more {{c3::hypotonic}} sweat.
This adaptation is mediated by {{c4::aldosterone}} in response to the net loss of Na+ from the body during the early stages of acclimatization. 
An individual who is not acclimatized and who sweats profusely can lose more than {{c5::30}} g of salt per day for the first few days.

In contrast, after several weeks of acclimatization, salt loss {{c1::falls}}.
Thus, an important benefit of physical training and heat acclimatization is the development of more dilute perspiration, which conserves {{c2::NaCl}} content and thus effective circulating volume during dehydration.
A single motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it activates is called a {{c1::motor unit.}}
The force exerted by a muscle during contraction depends on {{c1::how many motor units are recruited}} and {{c1::how frequently each of the active motor neurons fire action potentials}}.
Motor units are recruited in {{c1::progressive order (from weakest to strongest).}}
Skeletal muscles can be classified as {{c1::fast-twitch(Type IIa and IIb)}} or {{c1::slow-twitch (Type I)}} .

Endurance training results in greater {{c1::oxidative}} capacity of muscle fibers. 

increased {{c1::O2 delivery}}
increased {{c1::cappillary supply }}
increased {{c1::mitochondrial content}}
Strength training results in motor units that can produce {{c1::more::more or less}} force because with strength training comes increased production of {{c1::actin and myosin::contractile proteins.}}
In response to contractile activity the energy consumption of skeletal muscles can easily rise more than {{c1::100 fold. }}
Physical performance can be defined in terms of {{c1::power}}, {{c1::speed,}} and {{c1::endurance}}.
Muscles are connected to bones by {{c1::tendons}}
Muscles are connected to other muscles by {{c1::ligaments}}

Order of Muscle Organization from Smallest to Largest:
{{c1::Actin (thin) and Myosin (thick)}} < {{c2::myofibrils}} < {{c3::muscle cell (fiber)}} < {{c4::fascicles}} < {{c5::muscle}}
{{c2::I}} band: light band either side of the Z line that contains {{c1::thin}} filaments
{{c1::A}} band: dark area between two Z lines that contains {{c2::thick filaments and thin filaments}}
{{c1::H}} band: light area located in the middle of the A band that contains {{c2::thick}} filaments
{{c1::M}} line: dark line in middle of sarcomere that contains proteins (myomesin) critical for organization and alignment of the {{c2::thick}} filaments.
In addition to actin, thin filaments include the proteins {{c1::troponin}} and {{c1::tropomyosin}} that regulate muscle contraction

Troponin Complex
TnT - interacts with {{c1::tropomyosin}}
TnC - interacts with {{c1::calcium}}
TnI - interacts with {{c1::myosin binding site}}, inhibiting it
The head of the {{c1::light}} chain of myosin regulates ATPase activity of myosin.
The head of the {{c1::alkali light}} chain of myosin stabilizes the myosin head

When a motor neuron sends out an action potential, its synaptic terminals release the neurotransmitter {{c1::acetylcholine}}, which diffuses across the synapse to the plasma membrane of the muscle fiber.

When a muscle fiber is in a resting state, the regulatory proteins {{c1::tropomyosin}} and {{c1::troponin}} block the myosin binding sites on the actin molecules. When {{c1::Ca2+}} binds to troponin, the tropomysosin moves away from the myosin binding sites, allowing contraction to occur.
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A muscle contracts when thin filaments sldie along thick filaments
A single motor neuron + the muscle fibers it activates is called the {{c1::motor unit}}.

The force exerted by a muscle during contraction depends on:
1) how {{c1::many}} motor units are recruited
2) how {{c1::frequently}} each of the active motor neurons fire action potentials
Motor units are recruited in a progressive order from the {{c1::smallest (weakest)}} to the {{c1::largest (strongest)}}
{{c1::Endurance}} training is considered sustained periods of low to moderate intensity performed several times per week. It results in greater {{c1::oxidative}} capacity of muscle fibers.
{{c1::Strength}} training is considered brief sets of high-intensity contractions performed several times per week It results in motor units that can produce more {{c1::force}}.
In response to contractile activity, the energy consumption of skeletal muscle can easily rise more than {{c1::100}}-fold

The body meets an increased energy demand by contractile activity of muscle by mobilizing energy stores both:
  - locally from {{c1::muscle glycogen}} and {{c1::triacylglycerols}}
  - systemically from {{c1::liver glycogen}} and {{c1::adipose tissue triacylglycerols}}

The body meets an increased energy demand by contractile activity of muscle by mobilizing energy stores both:
  - locally from {{c1::muscle glycogen}} and {{c1::triacylglycerols}}
  - systemically from {{c1::liver glycogen}} and {{c1::adipose tissue triacylglycerols}}

Types of Physical Performance:
- {{c1::Power}}: typically last a few seconds or less
- {{c1::Speed}}: For spurts of activity that last several seconds to a minute
- {{c1::Endurance}}: For activities that last > 1 minute but have low power requirements
For a {{c1::power}} event, we have to use ATP we already have. Once used, we replensih it by combining ADP + creatine to make ATP + creatine using {{c1::creatine phosphokinase::enzyme}}.
Muscles are connected to bones by {{c1::tendons}}.
A muscle pulls the bone to which it is attached - it can only move the bone in {{c1::oneone/two}} direction/s.
Back and forth movement of body parts involves {{c1::antagonists}}, a pair of muscles or muscle groups that can pull the same bone in opposite directions.
While one antagonist {{c1::contracts}}, the other relaxes.
Each {{c1::muscle}} is made up of a hierarchy of smaller parallel strands, from the muscle itself down to the contractile protein molecules that produce body movements
A number of {{c1::fascicles}} makes up a muscle.
Each {{c1::muscle cell (fiber)}} is a long, cylindrical cell that has many nuclei.
Most of the volume of the muscle cell (fiber) is occupied by hundreds or thousands of {{c1::myofibrils}}.
Myofibrils are discrete bundles of proteins that include the contractile proteins {{c1::actin}} (thin filaments) and {{c1::myosin}} (thick filaments)
In addition to actin, thin filaments include the proteins; {{c1::troponin}} and {{c1::tropomyosin}}
A muscle contracts when {{c1::thin}} filaments slide along {{c1::thick}} filaments
Signals from the {{c1::CNS}}, conveyed by motor neurons are required to initiate and sustain muscle contraction.

When a motor neuron sends out an action potential, its synaptic terminals release the neurotransmitter {{c1::acetylcholine}}, which diffuses across the synapse to the plasma membrane of the muscle fiber.

When a motor neuron sends out an action potential, its synaptic terminals release the neurotransmitter {{c1::acetylcholine}}, which diffuses across the synapse to the plasma membrane of the muscle fiber.

Motor Neuron Stimulation of muscle
The action potential causes channels in the {{c1::ER}} to open, releasing {{c1::Ca2+}} ions into the cytoplasmic fluid.
When a muscle fiber is in a resting state, the regulatory proteins {{c2::tropomyosin}} and {{c2::troponin}} block the myosin binding sites on the actin molecules.
When Ca2+ binds to troponin, the {{c1::tropomyosin}} moves away from the myosin binding sites, allowing {{c1::contraction}} to occur.

When motor neurons stop sending action potentials to the muscle fibers, the ER pumps Ca2+ back out of the cytoplasmic fluid (Into the {{c1::ER}}), binding sites on the actin molecules are again {{c1::blocked::blocked/unblocked}}, the sarcomeres stop contracting, and the muscle {{c2::relaxes::tenses/relaxes}}
